verses.text: If you are appointed to preside at a banquet, do not exalt yourself, but act among the guests as one of them. Take care of their needs, then sit down.
verses.comment: Here, humility is emphasized for those in positions of honor—echoing Christ’s teaching to take the lowest place (Luke 14:10). True authority is found in humble service.

verses.text: When your work is done, take your place, so you may be merry with them; and for your good management, receive a crown.
verses.comment: Service with diligence leads to joy and reward—paralleling the parable of the talents, where the faithful steward is given a share in his master’s joy.

verses.text: Speak, you elder, for it is fitting for you, but with sound judgment, and do not interrupt the music.
verses.comment: Wisdom accompanies age, but restraint is necessary. Discerning when (and how) to speak shows spiritual maturity and respect for order.

verses.text: Do not pour out words where they are not needed, and do not show yourself unwise by talking too much.
verses.comment: Silent wisdom is often more powerful than many words. The call to prudence and self-control anticipates New Testament teachings on taming the tongue (James 1:19).

verses.text: As a signet of carbuncle set in gold, so is a melody played at a banquet.
verses.comment: Just as a jewel is set to enhance its beauty, so fitting music enhances joy in proper context. The appreciation for harmony points to the goodness of creation.

verses.text: A ruby seal on a gold mounting is a musical performance at a wine banquet.
verses.comment: Repetition emphasizes that fitting beauty and order in celebration reflect God’s order and the goodness of joy when expressed rightly.

verses.text: Speak, young man, if it is required of you, but few words, and only when asked twice.
verses.comment: Youth are called to humility and readiness to listen, learning wisdom before speaking, reflecting the virtue of obedience to elders.

verses.text: Sum up your words, say much in few; be as someone who knows and yet is silent.
verses.comment: Conciseness in speech models humility and wisdom, qualities often attributed in both Old and New Testament to the righteous.

verses.text: If you are among great men, do not presume; and when the elders are speaking, do not talk too much.
verses.comment: Proper reverence for authority and elders is a mark of humility. This is a foundation for order in the community and for rightly ordered worship.

verses.text: Lightning flashes before the thunder sounds, and favor precedes a humble person.
verses.comment: Just as order is seen in nature, God's favor is drawn to humility, foreshadowing Christ's teaching, 'whoever humbles himself will be exalted' (Luke 18:14).

verses.text: Rise early, and seek instruction, and you will find wisdom.
verses.comment: Diligence in seeking wisdom is rewarded; this is spiritual as well as practical advice, pointing to the value of study and perseverance.

verses.text: The pursuit of wisdom starts with sincere desire; watch at her gates and you will be filled with joy.
verses.comment: Imagery of waiting at wisdom’s gates resembles longing for intimacy with God—anticipating Jesus’ call to knock and seek (Matt. 7:7).

verses.text: The seeker of wisdom will find favor, and live in joy.
verses.comment: Wisdom is portrayed as a path to happiness, prefiguring the meaning of blessedness found in Christ’s Beatitudes (Matt. 5:3-12).

verses.text: Do not neglect a commandment, and in the struggles of life, rely on wisdom; for the Lord's way is sure, and wisdom guards those who love her.
verses.comment: Obedience and reliance on divine wisdom protect the faithful. Spiritual life includes both external law and interior devotion.

verses.text: He who trusts in her will inherit glory, and where she enters, the Lord will bless.
verses.comment: Embrace of wisdom leads to honor and divine blessing—a promise of spiritual inheritance.

verses.text: Those who fear the Lord will judge truthfully, and a faithful heart walks with wisdom.
verses.comment: Right judgment comes from proper reverence for God. Fear of the Lord leads to wisdom—a theme that runs from Proverbs through the Gospels.

verses.text: The lawless man will not accept correction, and finds excuses for doing as he pleases.
verses.comment: Resistance to truth and discipline reflects a rebellious heart. Christ rebukes those who prefer darkness to light (John 3:19-20).

verses.text: A person of sound judgment reflects in his heart before acting; but one without understanding acts in haste.
verses.comment: Careful discernment is a fruit of wisdom and aligns with New Testament admonition to be quick to hear, slow to speak, and slow to anger.

verses.text: Listen to your conscience, for it will warn you. You will not be reproached if you heed it.
verses.comment: This foreshadows Paul’s teaching about the law written on the heart (Rom. 2:15). An attentive conscience is essential for moral life.

verses.text: Do not be reckless in your deeds nor stubborn on a wrong path.
verses.comment: Prudence and conversion go hand in hand. Turning away from error is a central message of both prophets and Jesus.

verses.text: Do not trust in your own strength as you travel alone, for many are the ways of danger.
verses.comment: Reliance on self is limited. In biblical spirituality, security is found in God’s protection and in the supportive community of believers.

verses.text: Beware of your own children, watch out for your companions, and in every act be careful to avoid evil.
verses.comment: Even those close to us may lead us into temptation unintentionally. Vigilance is needed to avoid sin, recalling Jesus’ command to 'watch and pray' (Matt. 26:41).

verses.text: Whatever you do, remember your end, and you will never do wrong.
verses.comment: Mindfulness of death and final judgment ('memento mori') is a path to holiness, fostering sobriety in action, just as Paul reminds believers to do all for God’s glory.

verses.text: He who keeps the Law multiplies offerings; he who heeds the commandments offers a peace offering.
verses.comment: True devotion is more than outward sacrifice—it comes from obedience of heart. Jesus links love of God to keeping his commandments (John 14:21), showing that grace fulfills the Law.
